rules.text: Diese Mastodon-Instanz wird als privates Hobby ohne Garantie für Verfügbarkeit betrieben. Es besteht kein Anspruch auf jederzeit funktionierenden Zugang zum Konto. Downtimes (Updates, Wartung, Migration etc) werden - soweit möglich - vorher angekündigt.

Es ist grundsätzlich jedermensch willkommen, egal welcher politischen, religiösen oder sexuellen Ausrichtung und geschlechtlicher Identität. Bei beleidigendem, diskriminierendem oder schlicht nervtötendem Verhalten werden die Admins (auch ohne Ankündigung) Accounts sanktionieren oder deaktivieren.

Wer meint, Transfrauen seien keine Frauen, wer denkt, man könne als Mann heute ja gar keine Komplimente mehr machen oder wer glaubt, es gäbe "Rassismus gegen Weiße", ist auf dieser Instanz falsch. Diese Instanz ist gedacht als Safe Space. Von diesem Ideal lassen sich die Admins leiten.

Es wird erwartet, dass alle Nutzenden in der Lage sind, sich selbst zur Wehr zu setzen und Querelen unter einander zu klären. Die Meinungsfreiheit erlaubt zwar auch hitzigen Debatten, die Admins lassen sich aber nicht von "false balance" leiten. Werden Grenzen überschritten, gelten Ziffern 2. und 3.

records.text: The highest court held that “gratuities” – that is, post-facto gifts and payments – are not technically “bribes”, and therefore not illegal. Bribes are only issued before the desired official act, you see, and their meaning is explicit; a more vague, less vulgarly transactional culture of “gratitude” for official acts, expressed in gifts and payments of great value, is supposed to be something very different.  https://go.upcontent.com/c7787cbb-7d4a-4cdf-97ff-65d83ca92a7c

records.text: SCOTUS basically legalized bribery or gratuities to public officials. Muts read. https://go.upcontent.com/c7787cbb-7d4a-4cdf-97ff-65d83ca92a7c In a shocking decision, SCOTUS has now blurred the line between bribery and gratitude to public officials. The highest court ruled that post-facto gifts are not considered bribes, opening the door to a new level of legal corruption. A must-read article by The Guardian exposes this dangerous loophole.

records.text: The highest court held that “gratuities” – that is, post-facto gifts and payments – are not technically “bribes”, and therefore not illegal. records.text: The highest court held that “gratuities” – that is, post-facto gifts and payments – are not technically “bribes”, and therefore not illegal. Bribes are only issued before the desired official act, you see, and their meaning is explicit; a more vague, less vulgarly transactional culture of “gratitude” for official acts, expressed in gifts and payments of great value, is supposed to be something very different.  https://go.upcontent.com/c7787cbb-7d4a-4cdf-97ff-65d83ca92a7c

records.text: The highest court held that “gratuities” – that is, post-facto gifts and payments – are not technically “bribes”, and therefore not illegal. Bribes are only issued before the desired official act, you see, and their meaning is explicit; a more vague, less vulgarly transactional culture of “gratitude” for official acts, expressed in gifts and payments of great value, is supposed to be something very different.  https://go.upcontent.com/c7787cbb-7d4a-4cdf-97ff-65d83ca92a7c

records.text: SCOTUS basically legalized bribery or gratuities to public officials. Muts read. https://go.upcontent.com/c7787cbb-7d4a-4cdf-97ff-65d83ca92a7c In a shocking decision, SCOTUS has now blurred the line between bribery and gratitude to public officials.
